thread.title: Milking time at the den of deadly snakes
thread.title_full: Milking time at the den of deadly snakes

title: Milking time at the den of deadly snakes
text:
1 March 2017 Milking time at the den of deadly snakes Snakebite is one of the world’s biggest killers. Nick Casewell takes venom from snakes to develop a revolutionary antivenom that will save thousands of lives “If you’re bitten and you’re bleeding, this one antivenom should save you regardless of the snake” Photographed for New Scientist by Kirstin Kidd 
“WE HAVE a hospital just across the road, with a store of our antivenoms,” says biologist Nick Casewell. That’s good to know, given that we are in a room stacked floor to ceiling with boxes holding the world’s deadliest snakes. There are rattlesnakes, puff adders, black mambas and more – if it can kill a human, it’s here. With about 250 animals from 40 different species, it’s one of the largest collections of venomous snakes in Europe. And it’s milking time.
